Following [Wei48], the number  $N_{g}$  of solutions to Equation 3) can be expressed as a character sum which we now recall. As usual, by a multiplicative character of  $\mathbb{F}_q$  we mean a character of the group  $\mathbb{F}_q^\times$  , i.e. a group homomorphism from  $\mathbb{F}_q^\times$  to  $\mathbb{C}^{\times}$  . As we only deal with multiplicative characters of  $\mathbb{F}_q$  , we'll simply call them characters. The trivial character will be denoted by  $\epsilon$  such that  $\epsilon (a) = 1$  for all  $a\in \mathbb{F}_q^\times$  . We extend the domain of a character  $\chi$  such that  $\chi (0) = 1$  if  $\chi = \epsilon$  and  $\chi (0) = 0$  otherwise.
